text:
December 5, 2025 – What if the future of war, politics, and your electric bill were all connected? In this must-hear conversation, veteran host Jim Puplava sits down with acclaimed energy expert and author Robert Bryce to expose the hidden battle for power—literally and figuratively—shaping today's world. From Ukraine’s grid warfare to skyrocketing U.S. utility prices and the explosive growth of AI data centers, they reveal how electricity is at the heart of global conflict, economic uncertainty, and the upcoming election. Don’t miss these sharp insights, real-world stories, and urgent questions about how we’ll keep the lights on in the decade ahead. Have any feedback, breaking news, or comments about today's show? Click here to send us a message.

Column: Robert Bryce | Substack

Related article: The Electricity War - Robert Bryce

Website: Robert Bryce - Author | Journalist

Recent book: A Question of Power: Electricity and the Wealth of Nations

YouTube channel: Robert Bryce - YouTube

X: @pwrhungry

To speak with any of our wealth advisors, feel free to Contact Us online or give us a call at (888) 486-3939.

Stay ahead of the news! Subscribe to our premium weekday podcast

Ways to follow us

Client website: Financial Sense Wealth Management

X: Financial Sense (@FinancialSense_) / X

LinkedIn: Financial Sense® Wealth Management: Overview | LinkedIn

YouTube: Financial Sense - YouTube

Apple Podcasts:Financial Sense Newshour - Podcast - Apple Podcasts

Spotify: Financial Sense(R) Newshour | Podcast on Spotify

Summary

Electricity as a Weapon: The Russia-Ukraine war marks the first major conflict where control of electricity infrastructure is central to military strategy and peace negotiations.

Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant: Never before has a power plant been part of a peace deal—Russia’s demand for half the output is unprecedented.

Grid Vulnerability: Both Ukraine and Russia are targeting each other’s power grids and energy facilities, with over 1,300 strikes reported against Ukraine’s sector alone.

Energy & Society: Disabling a nation’s electric grid cripples hospitals, emergency services, water, manufacturing, and the ability to wage war.

Rising U.S. Utility Rates: Electricity prices are spiking nationwide, driven by flat supply, soaring demand from AI data centers, and costly policies favoring wind, solar, and batteries.

Land Use Conflicts: Rapid expansion of high-voltage transmission lines, data centers, and renewable projects faces growing local opposition and regulatory hurdles.

Natural Gas Dominance: Despite hopes for nuclear, the U.S. is set to meet surging demand with new natural gas plants, not rapid nuclear deployment.

Labor & Supply Chain Shortages: Construction of new energy infrastructure is being slowed by skilled labor shortages and dependence on critical minerals from abroad.

Political Impact: Electricity affordability is emerging as a top issue for 2025 elections, crossing partisan lines and fueling debates about technology, energy policy, and the future of American industry.

Commodities & the Future: The drive to reshape the U.S. grid, reindustrialize, and support tech growth hinges on access to commodities like copper, uranium, and rare earths.

Transcript

Jim Puplava:

Well, if you've been following the news, you know the President is trying to meet with Putin and bring about a peace agreement for the Ukraine war. But one of the big stories about that war is electricity. You haven't heard about it. Joining me on the program is Robert Bryce. Robert, you recently wrote an article called "Electricity War," and I'm just reading here from the opening: more than any conflict in history, the Russia-Ukraine war has been about electricity. So let's talk about that because I hadn't heard that anywhere until I read your piece.

Robert Bryce:

Well, thanks. You know, I've been following the power business for a while. My latest book is A Question of Power: Electricity and the Wealth of Nations. I've done two documentaries on this. This is the world's most important form of energy. And it's clear that when you look at how this war has gone on, electricity has been front and center. I think one of the key points—and what spurred me to write this article, Jim—was that in the 28-point peace proposal or plan that Trump put forward, one of the tenets was that the Russians would get half the output of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant. This is unprecedented. In the spoils of war, there has never been a power plant included in any peace deal—this is the very first time. And I think it's the ninth largest nuclear power plant in the world. So clearly, the Russians want this as one of their objectives. And the Trump administration is essentially saying, "Well, yeah, sure, if that's what you want, we'll give you half the output." But then you consider the number of attacks—missile attacks, etc.—on nuclear power plants, transformers, and so on, and it's clear this is, in fact, an electricity war.

Jim Puplava:

So when you look at this—and this isn't the first time—you talked about, in the first Gulf War, the U.S.-led bombing campaign nearly destroyed Saddam Hussein's electricity infrastructure. If you take out electricity, just think about the world we live in: you turn on the lights, you have refrigerators, your iPad, iPod, whatever it is. Our society runs on electricity. You take out electricity, what happens?

Robert Bryce:

Well, electricity—the electric grid—is the mother network. It's the network upon which all of our critical societal systems depend: hospitals, water, wastewater, emergency services, communications—all depend on the grid. So it's no surprise that in the Korean War, Vietnam War, and then in the Iraq wars, the electric infrastructure was a prime target for the U.S. military. Now we've seen—I'm just remembering my numbers here—in January, a Ukrainian official claimed Russian forces had launched nearly 1,300 strikes on Ukraine's energy sector, including more than 800 electric substations, distribution and power lines, more than 250 strikes on energy generation facilities, and 30 on gas facilities. Then add in the attacks the Ukrainians have launched on Russian facilities, and again, this is unprecedented—it's never happened at this scale before.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, one of the negotiating items—and Trump didn't do it—but the Ukrainians wanted long-range missiles so they could go farther and damage Russia's energy infrastructure. In your article, you talk about how, if you destroy your adversary's grid, you weaken their entire society, including their ability to wage war.

Robert Bryce:

Well, sure. If you have a nuclear—or any kind of—manufacturing plant to make munitions, missiles, tanks, jeeps, automobiles, bullets, rifles, you need power. If you ruin a country's electric grid, you not only make the overwhelming majority of people in the country miserable, you destroy their ability to manufacture the tools of war. But I think it's also important to remember—here we are in December, Jim, and winter is coming to Ukraine. This was a big threat before: the ability of Ukrainians to keep their power grid up during the depths of winter. Putin has shown no interest in declaring peace or any kind of peace deal, in my view, and I think he'd be happy to just continue the war, continue degrading Ukraine's infrastructure, and force ordinary Ukrainians through another fierce winter. This is a way to wage war. As I ended the piece, Putin now has the ability to weaponize winter, and that sure looks like what he wants to do.

Jim Puplava:

Well, just look at what happened to Europe when he invaded Ukraine. In the case of Germany, where they shut down their nuclear power plants, their gas plants, or their coal plants, they were left stranded and vulnerable to Russian blackmail, essentially.

Robert Bryce:

Sure. And remember the Zaporizhzhia plant, which I mentioned before—it has about 5,700 megawatts of generation capacity. As I said, it's the ninth largest nuclear plant in the world. That was one of the first objectives of the Russian invasion. They captured that plant within about two or three weeks—or, I'm sorry, it was just eight days after Putin launched the invasion. So this has been a strategic goal of the Russians from the very beginning: to capture key parts of the Ukrainian power grid.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah. I just wonder, if Trump can't get Putin to the table to negotiate peace, if he just gives the Ukrainians long-range missiles, that would escalate the war, but it could get more serious.

Robert Bryce:

Well, exactly. And this has been something—remember, this is a multi-level game at hand here, Jim. So yes, the U.S. could give the Ukrainians long-range missiles, but is Putin just going to see that as an act of war by the Americans, that they're using the Ukrainians now fully as a proxy to attack Russia? Further, we still need the Russians for other reasons. Yes, we've embargoed their oil exports—note, we haven't embargoed their uranium exports. Why? Because still today, about 20% of the nuclear fuel used in the U.S. reactor fleet comes from Russia. So, you know, the possibility of declaring all-out war against Russia is there. I was talking to a relative over the holidays; he said, "Well, we just haven't pressured the Russians enough." And I'm thinking, "Well, the Russians have a lot of cards here too." NATO—we could talk about NATO, we could talk about a whole lot of other things, but are we really serious about declaring full-scale war on the Russians over Ukraine? I don't think we are. And, you know, do I want my sons—I have two of them—to go to Ukraine to fight the Russians? No. Hell no.

Jim Puplava:

No. It's interesting because we're finding out—like we did with COVID—about supply chain difficulties, where you couldn't get stuff. I mean, I can't think of anything I get from Amazon or something I buy that doesn't say "Made in China."

Robert Bryce:

Yeah.

Jim Puplava:

As for rare earths, Russia has a number of key minerals, including uranium. So it really leaves us vulnerable. Now that we're on the topic of electricity, I'd like to transition to probably one of the hottest topics coming up in next year's election, which is affordability. And right at the top of that, Robert, is electricity prices. It was on the ballot in New Jersey—New Jersey utility prices are up 26%. It was on the ballot in Virginia, where most of the world's data centers are located. What we're seeing is politicians and the media blaming three groups: tech companies with their AI data centers, utilities, and then the catch-all—Trump.

Robert Bryce:

Sure.

Jim Puplava:

So let's talk about what is driving these utility costs. We've had discussions in the past—probably for the first time in multiple decades, various utilities are becoming more like growth stocks because of the energy demands for electricity.

Robert Bryce:

Sure. And isn't it interesting, Jim, you know, you're an investment guy. For years, the utility sector was viewed as this sleepy part of the business—what you buy for widows and orphans and grandmas; you buy the utility stocks and collect the dividends. Now stocks like Vistra and Constellation have far outperformed the S&P 500 because of the profits they stand to make as independent power producers. Why is that? It's because of this massive increase in demand for power. As you know, Jim, electric demand in the U.S. for the last 20 years has essentially been flat, growing at less than 1% a year. And now, all of a sudden, we're looking at 2, 3, 4% per year growth. The EPRI—the Electric Power Research Institute—is estimating AI is going to need another 50 gigawatts of new generation capacity by 2030. So suddenly, the power business is "sexy." And as you point out, in various states across the country, rates are skyrocketing. Why is that? Well, these states, they've been drinking the Kool-Aid on wind, solar, and batteries, and now the bill is coming due. They're finding out they don't have enough power to meet demand. Further, because of AI and data centers, they're trying to build a lot of high-voltage transmission. And what happens in electricity and plumbing—poop rolls downhill. The ratepayers are getting stuck with the bill.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah. Let's talk about wind and solar. I live in California, the land of fruits and nuts, and we're a prime example. We've got the highest gasoline prices in the country, the highest tax rates, but also the highest utility prices. That's because in California, we've shut down two nuclear power plants—one's been postponed from shutting down, but we shut down one; we shut down our coal-fired plants, and we built these wind farms and solar panel farms. It produces intermittent power, and we don't have the battery backup to make that consistent.

Robert Bryce:

Sure. And you can't build gas pipelines either. All of these things combined, Jim, are driving up California's power prices. Further, this is just a teaser for what's to come because the utilities in California are still facing net zero mandates. They're going to try to build a lot more wind and solar. They want to push a lot more high-voltage transmission. All of this is incredibly expensive. Just on the transmission side alone, we're talking tens of billions of dollars in additional costs—if those lines can even be built. That's the other part of this: land use conflicts over high-voltage transmission. You mentioned Virginia—whole sections of the state are opposing high-voltage transmission projects proposed to serve data centers. Local folks are saying, "Look, we don't want these big projects, these power lines coming over our neighborhood. We don't get any benefit from them." Again, another example of how energy policy and land use policy are interconnected.

Jim Puplava:

You know, it's amazing because we live in this technological society. I just think of all the things I have to charge at night: my iWatch, my iPhone, my iPad, my iMac—all these devices that use electricity, which make our lives convenient and give us what we want. But the other side of that, Robert, is our use of the Internet and AI. We're on e-commerce—think of all that. It requires data centers to house the information we're using. So there seems to be a disconnect between the life I live and what's necessary to produce that life.

Robert Bryce:

Well, it's funny as you say that, Jim. Well, first, on the iWatch—you make a good living; you can afford a good mechanical watch. Maybe you don't have to get a Rolex, but spring for a nice watch! You're too old for those digital things. But you're right, you know, there's this attitude of "well, I don't want it here, put it somewhere else." I don't like the term NIMBY—I think it's a slur. Everyone, everywhere cares about their neighborhood. But as you were saying that, it reminds me of the old maxim in the trash business: everybody wants their trash picked up, but nobody wants it put down. That applies, I think, to data centers. The concerns of local communities are real and valid. These data centers—they're big boxes, they're noisy, they draw tremendous amounts of power; nobody lives there, they change the character of neighborhoods, and they're massive power draws. That's why in Ireland, around Dublin, you can't build data centers—there's a prohibition. In New Mexico, new radical rules dramatically reduce where data centers can locate. So this is happening in a lot of places.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, we recently interviewed Mark Mills, and he was talking about the amount of electricity and land space. Have you seen the amount of land these buildings occupy? I mean, it's like a miniature city—are they that huge?

Robert Bryce:

Well, interesting you bring that up—my wife Lauren and I just drove back from Denver, and yesterday we went through Abilene and stopped by the Stargate project, OpenAI's data center that's going up there, Jim. It's about two square miles—1,100 acres, so 640 acres per square mile. So more than one and a half square miles. I've been to a county fair and a goat rope; I've seen a few construction sites, but I don't know that I've seen one this big, with that much dirt being moved. You can see it on Google Maps. We drove along one road on just one side of it—it was a full mile. The number of contractors, the cranes—it was truly staggering. If built as Sam Altman says, and that's a big "if," it'll be 5 gigawatts—that's 5,000 megawatts. For comparison, I live in Austin, Texas. Austin Energy, our municipally owned utility, has 4,000 megawatts of installed capacity.

Jim Puplava:

And that's for the whole city.

Robert Bryce:

That's for the whole city of over a million people. So one data center—this big AI project OpenAI is pushing—will use more power than the entire city of Austin. It's just truly staggering in scale.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, I don't think utilities were ready for this kind of demand. Plus, we have an aging infrastructure. And on top of AI, Robert, we also have this reindustrialization. I can't turn on a financial channel each week without seeing another company—this week Eli Lilly—building a $5 billion manufacturing plant. So it's not just AI centers, it's the manufacturing we're trying to bring back and build factories. That's going to take electricity and power. It's enormous.

Robert Bryce:

It is. And as you point out, this whole push has caught the utility sector flat-footed. Also, in terms of capital allocation—you're a numbers guy, a money guy—I just did these calculations. If you look at the big five tech companies—Amazon, Meta, Google, Microsoft, and Apple—their combined market capitalization is around $15 trillion. The combined market cap of 108 U.S. utilities (all electric, gas, water utilities—the biggest in the U.S.) is about $1.6 trillion. Just the big five tech companies are worth $15 trillion and they're demanding massive amounts of power. So it's a mismatch in capital availability, a mismatch in market strength. The big tech companies—there's a queue for gas-fired turbines. How much does it cost to jump the queue? They'll jump the queue. The scale of these buildouts and the amounts of money involved are truly unprecedented.

Jim Puplava:

You know, I just wonder, Robert, if they can even produce this, because we're looking at natural gas for power in the next five years—that's what we see. And then after that, maybe nuclear. If they could accelerate these small nuclear power plants—so you build a data center out in Timbuktu, away from any residential area, and then pop in a small nuclear power plant. It seems that would be a solution, but you've got to get through the regulatory red tape and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Robert Bryce:

Sure. I like how you put that—"pop one in," like it's a car battery or something. Easy to say, Jim. I'm adamantly pro-nuclear and have been saying the same thing for 15 years: natural gas to nuclear. But it's clear—and I've lectured on this; I'm going to be in Orlando next week talking about this very thing. The caption for my presentation is "AI, Gas, and the Grid." There is simply no way nuclear is going to provide any sizable amount of new power to the AI/data center race. It's all going to be gas. Why? Because we can't deploy new nuclear fast enough. I think we'll be lucky to deploy 10 gigawatts of new nuclear by 2035. We'll probably build 100 gigawatts of new gas by then. So it's a gas story. AI is a gas story—full stop.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, we're invested in natural gas and pipelines for that very reason. Because I know the way Washington works—the red tape and bureaucracy you have to go through. And not only that, Robert, it's like we're finding with technology—we can't make this high-tech stuff without rare earth minerals, and you can't run nuclear power plants without uranium, and we're dependent on foreigners for a lot of this.

Robert Bryce:

Well, you're right. I've written a lot about China, supply chains, and rare earths. You're absolutely right—copper is a strategic element. But don't forget the rare earths are also critical for nuclear: samarium, gadolinium, europium, dysprosium—several are required by the nuclear sector. None of this happens in a vacuum. Just back to the SMR story—I published a piece a few days ago about the collapse in share prices of several pure-play SMR companies: Oklo, NuScale, Terrestrial, and Nano Nuclear in November. Mr. Market has been looking at those companies and saying, "I'm not sure I buy this story," because they're all many years away from commercial deployment and even further from profitability. They'll have to raise billions in new capital, and at NuScale for one, they're massively diluting existing shareholders. I'm hopeful for SMRs, but I wouldn't bet against the incumbent companies like GE Vernova and BWX Technologies—they have big balance sheets, lots of experience in manufacturing, they're not startups, and they know what they're doing when it comes to building reactors.

Jim Puplava:

Oh, absolutely. So how do you think this plays out? Next year is a key congressional election, and the number one issue on the ballot is going to be affordability. With affordability, they're really talking about electricity. If we're talking about rising food costs, I can make some substitutes—maybe buy fresh food instead of packaged, or go to a lower cut of beef. I've noticed in our supermarket they've got lower cuts of beef, which are cheaper. Costco cleared out a good portion of their beef section and is featuring seafood, which is cheaper. But with electricity, you can't substitute. You either turn on the lights or you don't. So how do you think this plays out? It's shaping up to be the number one issue in the election next year.

Robert Bryce:

It is interesting, Jim, and it could be one of those rare issues where Democrats and Republicans align. It's a populist issue. For instance, Josh Hawley—a Republican in Missouri—railed against the Grain Belt Express high-voltage transmission line and got it killed. In Virginia, as you pointed out, candidates ran against data centers, saying they'll make them pay their fair share. That's Democrats running against big tech—and nobody likes big tech. So how this shakes out will be really interesting in November. Republicans may be on the defensive because Trump has had the big tech bros in the Oval Office and at the inauguration. Does he really want to stand next to Zuckerberg and Bezos as they build these data centers, or will he flip the script and say he's for consumers now? To be clear, we can't blame all the electricity price rises on data centers and big tech, but they're an easy target. This is about land use, affordability, local neighborhood issues—and these cross partisan lines.

Jim Puplava:

You know, this is the problem with the media today. It's easy, when there's a particular problem, to find somebody to blame it on—"Okay, it's the tech guys, that's why this is going on." It's a lot more complex, as you talk about in your article and others have discussed: the green transition, more wind and solar, distant transmission lines, distribution rates, and so on. It's more complex, but if you can find someone to blame, it makes the story simple—"Ah, okay, it's the tech guys."

Robert Bryce:

Well, I take your point. I'll add that what I fear—and I think my fear is well-founded—is that the big investor-owned utilities are only focused on their massive capital expenditure programs for the next few years: funding new high-voltage transmission, funding new generation. While they may not be able to say this is all for data centers, to them it doesn't matter. I've watched this for a long time. What do the big utilities care about? Getting as much of their expenditures into the rate base as possible. So far, public utility commissions have said, "Sure, no problem." We've seen that here in Texas, with Oncor proposing a 765kV line running from east to west out to the Permian Basin. The demand is in the Permian. Why build a power line across the state? Makes no sense—unless you're a utility that wants a rate base and an $80 billion project. Then it makes a lot of sense.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah. So this is going to play out. It's going to be the number one issue. It's funny—as you mentioned, we started out thinking about utilities. Me, being in the investment business, if I had someone older, conservative, wanted income, I'd put them in utilities: bread and butter, safe, not volatile. It's a whole different ballgame today with utilities.

Robert Bryce:

Oh, absolutely. It's interesting to take a step back and look at the utility sector and what's happening in commodities. I haven't checked the natural gas price today, but this cold spell has hit—sent gas prices up, I think it's over $5, the Henry Hub spot price. Remember, just two years ago, the average price for natural gas in the U.S. was $2.20. We're now more than double that. Then add in what we're seeing in the copper market, uranium, rare earths, all of these technologies require digging stuff out of the ground—and a lot of stuff. That's going to be a pinch point. I'll just add one other quick point: it's also about labor, Jim. This is another macro theme we've talked about before. You can talk about building all the data centers in the world, but you have to have skilled labor—men and some women willing to be there in the mud, cold, dark, and rain. The supply of those workers is very tight right now.

Jim Puplava:

Oh, it's incredible. I just added onto my house—putting in a hyperbaric chamber. I had an electrician out for three 20-amp circuits to power this, six hours a day: $1,500. If I had kids today thinking about college, I'd say go to trade school. You can become an electrician and in a couple of years you're making six figures. Here's an interesting thing I'll throw—

Robert Bryce:

And you happily paid that $1,500 too, didn't you? It wasn't a big expense for you, but to get it done right, you paid that. That's what we're seeing. I was at a conference a few weeks ago—a man who runs a lot of linemen, journeyman linemen. He's seeing other companies poaching his people, paying as much as $500 per day per diem to work in remote areas. The wage war to capture these skilled laborers is another big inflationary part of the economy that doesn't get much attention.

Jim Puplava:

Well, and this is something you're seeing—what's rather interesting, I'm looking at this from maybe a 40,000-foot level—but if you look at the '70s and '80s, we outsourced manufacturing, so we got the rust belt, blue-collar workers lost their jobs. Now, with AI, it's white-collar jobs being lost. The Wall Street Journal recently said it'll be the worst job market for graduating seniors next year. I can't turn on or pick up a newspaper without seeing some company laying off workers—Amazon, 40,000, because of AI. So to me, we don't have enough electricians, welders, plumbers, carpenters. Life is looking good for a blue-collar worker or tradesman over the next decade.

Robert Bryce:

Auto mechanics—I'll add that in. That's another key issue. There was also one—yes, using Bureau of Labor Statistics data, the Economic Policy and Innovation Center came out with a report last month. Since 1995, the participation rate in the labor force of men aged 16 to 24 has dropped from 71% to 55%, along with all the other social pathologies associated with increased loneliness, time online, and disengagement from social groups. The decline in labor force connection promises more social and economic problems. It's not just the folks our age—the people in their dotage, right? The workforce of the future is shrinking, and the men who should be starting their careers are dropping out of the workforce. That's very worrisome.

Jim Puplava:

It's an incredible time. We're going through probably one of the biggest transitions. I don't think we've fully grasped what's happening: reshoring, supply chain shortages we're trying to correct. We're scrambling to catch up for policy mistakes, in my opinion, made three or four decades ago.

Robert Bryce:

It is. It's funny you say that because I ask people about this a lot—is it more uncertain now? I have the sense, as you do, that we're in conflict with China—some of that self-imposed, right? Trump's on-again, off-again tariffs. I won't say we're at the brink of war with Russia, but we're in conflict. We have a president who one day goes this way, the next day the other. We're shooting supposed drug smugglers in the water—wait a minute! The level of uncertainty, economically, with massive debt in the U.S., where we're paying more for our debt than for national defense, upheaval in commodity markets, layoffs in oil, tech, and retail—it's an incredible amount of uncertainty. I wish I knew what was going to happen next, but I'm just trying to be defensive, be smart, and plan to keep working because I'm too young to retire—what else would I do?

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, it's amazing. We certainly live in interesting times. We shifted, Robert, probably three or four years ago—I'm now a little over 30% in commodities for clients: oil, gas, gold, silver, uranium, all these things. All this stuff we're trying to do—reshoring, the grid, energy—it takes raw materials. The government even came out and declared copper a strategic material. Silver is now a strategic material. We want to make all this stuff, but to do that—especially if you're bringing back manufacturing—you need commodities. You need stuff to make stuff.

Robert Bryce:

You're right. Let me see—I'm just looking at the Henry Hub price today. The front month price for January delivery is $5.31. What a massive jump. Of course, it's winter and prices always go up, but we've also seen the massive run-up in copper. Copper has been fairly flat for a while, but now, with the problems at the Grasberg mine in Indonesia, copper's at $5.37 per pound—that's up 35% for the year. Silver's up over 100%. Gold's up 60%. Platinum's up 84%. It truly is a remarkable time. Even despite the run-up in gas prices, U.S. natural gas is still about half the cost of Europe or Asia. The key for the U.S. is to keep energy and power cheap, abundant, and reliable. That's the key to maintaining the U.S. advantage over the rest of the world.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, Jensen Huang, CEO of Nvidia, was on this week talking about how, if it weren't for the energy coming out now with the Trump administration taking off regulations, what he's trying to do and what other tech companies are trying to do wouldn't be possible. It's impossible.

Robert Bryce:

It's—AI is a power play. It's a play for watts. There was an interesting article the other day about Nvidia's chipsets: their power density, their power demand, keeps going up. It's a little counterintuitive to me, Jim, because my fifth book was Smaller Faster Lighter Denser Cheaper. The history of the computer age has been just that—smaller, faster, lighter, denser, cheaper—since ENIAC. The power demand went down, and the computing power went up. But now, with large language models and the rest, even with the increased efficiency of chips, the data demand and computational power demand have grown so fast that the power sector can't keep up with the compute sector.

Jim Puplava:

I've watched this over three or four decades. Right now, it's sort of the NIMBY idea: we don't want data centers; big tech are the bad people; utilities are also bad. Maybe we'll go against them or see what politicians try to do. Then we'll start having energy shortages, blackouts, because we don't have enough energy. Then the pendulum swings in the opposite direction.

Robert Bryce:

It may well be, but I think the land use conflicts are not going away. What still beggars belief is how—now, I have plenty of criticisms of the Trump administration, plenty—but on the energy front, I think they've been absolutely right on pretty much everything. What we haven't seen, Jim, is a similar move in Europe. Instead, the Brits, Germans, the EU—Ursula von der Leyen, the head of the EU Commission—just yesterday or the day before said, "We're moving toward energy independence." I thought, "You are so blind, you don't know what you're talking about," because they continue to think they're going to solve energy problems with wind, solar, and batteries. Just since January 1 in England, Ireland, and Scotland, there have been, I think, 65 rejections of wind and solar projects. So the idea that they're going to run on wind and solar—you can't build it. Local communities all over the British Isles are saying, "Take this stuff and put it somewhere else."

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, it's amazing. You keep talking about this land use thing—it's not only just the land use for wind farms and solar, but now you throw in data centers. And let's not forget, if you're going to build something like a Taiwan Semiconductor plant in Phoenix or Intel or Apple, those plants take massive amounts of land. We want to bring back all these factories, but you can't just go in the middle of a city, tear down buildings, and put up a two-square-mile manufacturing plant.

Robert Bryce:

That's certainly true. I mentioned I was in Abilene just yesterday, and this Stargate project is located northwest of Abilene. It's just a big area with cattle grazing and mesquite and huisache—so there's plenty of land in Texas, but that's not necessarily the case in Virginia, Data Center Alley near Dulles Airport. That's very land-constrained. The theme we're seeing with data centers is that the latest numbers show that some of the biggest installations are going where the gas is. I mentioned Abilene—almost spitting distance from the Permian Basin. In that part of Texas, natural gas is super cheap and abundant. Same in the Haynesville—Entergy is building a big gas-fired plant in Louisiana for Facebook. In Ohio, over the Utica, Facebook is building more capacity. In Pennsylvania, near the Marcellus, a lot of data centers are going in there. The hyperscalers—the big tech companies—are putting data centers where the gas is because that's their only way to get the power they need. It's a gas-to-power play.

Jim Puplava:

All right, well, Robert, as we close, any parting thoughts? Do you think Putin settles with Trump and the Ukrainians on this?

Robert Bryce:

Well, he hasn't settled yet. We've been looking at this same deal for two, three weeks now. I don't know. I wish he would, Jim. I hope and pray there's some settlement, but I don't see what—Trump's motivation is clear: he wants to see an end to this and call himself the peacemaker. But what's Putin's motivation to quit? I think he has a lot of incentives to keep the war going. I hope I'm wrong, but as he hasn't quit now, what incentives have changed that would make him do something different? From everything I hear—and it's only that—the Russian economy is doing fine. The longer the war goes, the more Putin is fine with that. As brutal as that is, I don't wish it to be true, but that's what it appears.

Jim Puplava:

Well, it's amazing because if he's successful in Ukraine, he's also been poking around in Europe. It's like resurrecting the old Soviet empire.

Robert Bryce:

It's a dangerous time. It's delicate to figure out the right way forward. I pray for peace, but I'm trying to be as sober about this as everything else. I want a good outcome, but again, this is just one of many uncertainties in a world that seems as fraught and dangerous as any time in my adult life.

Jim Puplava:

Hopefully, we can bring the country together on things, because at least in my lifetime, I've never seen the country as divided as it is today. You'd probably have to go back to the Civil War to see this much division.

Robert Bryce:

That's a good point. I don't know that that's true—I guess Ken Burns has a line, he's been talking lately, he has a new documentary coming out, and he said, "The country has always been divided. What's different now?" I think that's probably true. But the vitriol is what's been hard, and unfortunately, the Trump administration has fanned the flames of some of that. The midterms are going to be interesting. I'm curious to see who's going to run in '28—who the Democrats will put up. It's clear Gavin Newsom is running. But who's going to prevail on the Republican side? Economics and affordability, particularly on energy, as you've talked about, will be front and center.

Jim Puplava:

Yeah, well, it looks like, at least from what I'm following, it could be Newsom and AOC. Among the candidates, Newsom seems to be at the top right now.

Robert Bryce:

He has the money, he's from a big state with a lot of electoral votes. He says he hasn't decided—he's decided. But he's from California, and as you say, the land of fruits and nuts. I think Republicans will say, "Do you really want a California-style regime nationally with all these insane climate policies?" They can point to his record on housing, a lot of things—he's vulnerable on his own record. There's no doubt the Democratic Party has moved further left and is now really the party of AOC, but Newsom—don't count him out. He's movie-star handsome, very good on the stump, but it's going to be a battle royale on the Republican side.

Jim Puplava:

Well, we live in interesting times. I'm just glad I own hard assets for my clients and we own some growth utilities. It's a different market. That's one of the things I've seen in the market over the years—every decade brings a different kind of cycle, stocks that drive it. Right now, I see the drive in commodity-type stocks. But anyway, as always, it's a pleasure having you on the program. I read your article, "The Electricity War," and I hadn't heard anyone talk about that. So I wanted to have you on. You're my electricity man, my expert buddy.

Robert Bryce:

That's very kind, thanks. Don't forget robertbryce.substack.com.

Jim Puplava:

Hey Robert, tell them about your two documentary films—they're excellent. If you really want to understand electricity and what's going on, people should go watch them. They're very interesting and well done.

Robert Bryce:

Thank you. I've actually made a couple of mini-documentaries—"mini docs"—with my daughter Mary. One is "Shrinking Fission" on SMRs, about seven minutes. We also made one earlier this year called "Sunblock: The Global Fight to Save Farmland from Big Solar." I also did a feature-length documentary in 2019 with Tyson Culver called "Juice: How Electricity Explains the World"—that's at juicethemovie.com. Then we did a five-part docuseries called "Juice: Power, Politics, and the Grid." Each segment's about 20 minutes, available at juicetheseries.com. All are free on YouTube. I'm easy to find—just search Robert Bryce on YouTube or Google. Thank you. I'm very proud of all the documentaries we've done—I'm very lucky to do what I do. It's my purpose and my passion, and I love to talk about this stuff.

Jim Puplava:

Well, you're very good at it, so I appreciate you coming on the program. Happy holidays, Merry Christmas, and a prosperous new year.

Robert Bryce:

Awesome. Thanks, Jim.

If you’re not already a subscriber to our weekday FS Insider podcast, click here to subscribe. For a link to our full podcast archive, see Financial Sense Newshour (All) and don't forget to subscribe on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or YouTube Podcasts!

title: Economic benefits of fighting climate change outweigh inaction - The Augusta Chronicle
description:
Here are some benefits of fighting climate change from various sources, including Yale Climate Connections.
The benefits of fighting climate change Cleaner air leads to fewer pollution-related illnesses, which means less money spent on medical treatments and fewer hospital admissions.
Here are some ways climate change impacts daily life from various sources, including the Environmental Defense Fund.
By reducing emissions, climate action lessens the frequency and intensity of these costly disruptions.
Erica Van Buren is the climate change reporter for The Augusta Chronicle, part of the USA TODAY Network.
text:
As greenhouse gas emissions surround the Earth, they trap the sun’s heat. Because of this, the planet is warming up, and the climate is changing, according to experts.

The world is now warming faster than at any point in recorded history. Warmer temperatures over time are changing weather patterns. This poses many risks to all forms of life, according to the United Nations Climate Action.

Here are some benefits of fighting climate change from various sources, including Yale Climate Connections.

The benefits of fighting climate change

Cleaner air leads to fewer pollution-related illnesses, which means less money spent on medical treatments and fewer hospital admissions.

Reducing emissions helps prevent crop losses, which can save billions of dollars annually and enhance food security.

Transitioning to clean energy means investment in building new infrastructure like solar, wind farms, and manufacturing clean vehicles, creating demand for skilled jobs like engineers, electricians, and construction workers.

In most parts of the world, new renewable energy projects are already the most affordable source of power.

Energy efficiency upgrades in homes and buildings can lead to substantial reductions in energy bills for households.

Investing in clean energy can decouple economies from the volatile price swings and geopolitical shocks of the global fossil fuel market.

Here are some ways climate change impacts daily life from various sources, including the Environmental Defense Fund.

Higher grocery prices due to crop failures.

Increased energy bills from heatwaves.

Infrastructure damage from floods.

Health risks include heat stress and respiratory issues.

Inaction on climate change exposes economies to massive costs from extreme weather events, infrastructure damage, and agricultural losses, according to the World Resources Institute. The global economic benefits from avoided damages and short-term improvements could increase globally by up to 3% by 2050.

By reducing emissions, climate action lessens the frequency and intensity of these costly disruptions.

Taking climate action in the United States can save at least $4 billion by the end of the century on road maintenance alone, according to Yale Climate Connections.

This reporting content is supported by a partnership with several funders and Journalism Funding Partners.

Erica Van Buren is the climate change reporter for The Augusta Chronicle, part of the USA TODAY Network. Connect with her at EVanBuren@gannett.com or on X: @EricaVanBuren32.

Article content

This revelation, emerging from life-cycle and supply chain audits, exposes the false claim behind Ottawa’s more than $50 billion experiment. A Volvo study found that manufacturing an EV generates 70 per cent more emissions than building a comparable conventional vehicle because battery production is energy-intensive and often powered by coal in countries such as China. Depending on the electricity grid, it can take years or never for an EV to offset that initial carbon debt.

Prime Minister Mark Carney paused the federal electric vehicle (EV) mandate for 2026 due to public pressure and corporate failures while keeping the 2030 and 2035 targets. The mandate requires 20 per cent of new vehicles sold in 2026 to be zero-emission, rising to 60 per cent in 2030 and 100 per cent in 2035. Carney inherited this policy crisis but is reluctant to abandon it.

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Industry failures and Trump tariffs forced Ottawa’s hand. Northvolt received $240 million in federal subsidies for a Quebec battery plant before filing for bankruptcy. Lion Electric burned through $100 million before announcing layoffs. Arrival, a U.K.-based electric van and bus manufacturer, collapsed entirely. Stellantis and LG Energy Solution extracted $15 billion for Windsor. Volkswagen secured $13 billion for St. Thomas.

The federal government committed more than $50 billion in subsidies and tax credits to prop up Canada’s EV industry. Ottawa defended these payouts as necessary to match the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act, which offers major incentives for EV and battery manufacturing. That is twice Manitoba’s annual operating budget. Every Manitoban could have had a two-year tax holiday with the public money Ottawa wasted on EVs.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Even with incentives, EVs reached only 15 per cent of new vehicle sales in 2024, far short of the mandated levels for 2026 and 2030. When federal subsidies ended in January 2025, sales collapsed to nine per cent, revealing the true level of consumer demand. Dealer lots overflowed with unsold inventory. EV sales also slowed in the U.S. and Europe in 2024, showing that cooling demand is a broader trend.

As economist Friedrich Hayek observed, “The curious task of economics is to demonstrate to men how little they really know about what they imagine they can design.” Politicians and bureaucrats cannot know what millions of Canadians know about their own needs. When federal ministers mandate which vehicles Canadians must buy and which companies deserve billions, they substitute the judgment of a few hundred officials for the collective wisdom of an entire market.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Bureaucrats draft regulations that determine the vehicles Canadians must purchase years from now, as if they can predict technology and consumer preferences better than markets.

Green ideology provided perfect cover. Invoke a climate emergency and fiscal responsibility vanishes. Question more than $50 billion in subsidies and you are labelled a climate denier. Point out the environmental costs of battery production, and you are accused of spreading misinformation.

History repeatedly teaches that central planning always fails. Soviet five-year plans, Venezuela’s resource nationalization and Britain’s industrial policy failures all show the same pattern. Every attempt to run economies from political offices ends in misallocation, waste and outcomes opposite to those promised. Concentrated political power cannot ever match the intelligence of free markets responding to real prices and constraints.

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Markets collect information that no central planner can access. Prices signal scarcity and value. Profits and losses reward accuracy and punish error. When governments override these mechanisms with mandates and subsidies, they impair the information system that enables rational economic decisions.

The EV mandate forced a technological shift and failed. Billions in subsidies went to failing companies. Taxpayers absorbed losses while corporations walked away. Workers lost their jobs.

Canada needs a full repeal of the EV mandate and a retreat from PMO planners directing market decisions. The law must be struck, not paused. The contrived 2030 and 2035 targets must be abandoned.

Markets, not cabinet ministers, must determine what technologies Canadians choose.

– Marco Navarro-Genie is vice-president of research at the Frontier Centre for Public Policy and co-author, with Barry Cooper, of Canada’s COVID: The Story of a Pandemic Moral Panic (2023).

name: Clean Energy
title: State needs more energy, sensible regulation - Williamsport Sun-Gazette
description:
In July, nearly two dozen companies gathered in Pittsburgh, along with President Donald Trump and other leaders, to announce investments in data centers and needed energy infrastructure.
data centers addressing water and energy use, emergency preparedness,” and more.
At a hearing before the Pennsylvania House Committee on Energy, several witnesses cautioned against the bill’s renewable mandate.
Josh Shapiro should drop his own attempts to tax reliable energy sources and force renewable energy on consumers.
Or are we truly going to work toward Pennsylvania energy dominance?
text:
In July, nearly two dozen companies gathered in Pittsburgh, along with President Donald Trump and other leaders, to announce investments in data centers and needed energy infrastructure. Totaling more than $90 billion, the expenditures would equal nearly ten percent of Pennsylvania’s gross domestic product, inducing a headline that described the prospect as “truly mind-blowing.”

Since then, some have begun erecting regulatory obstacles to this development. Presented as consumer protections, many are more likely to be economy killers — and “mind-blowing” for would-be reformers of 164,000 regulations already dampening Pennsylvania’s business climate.

Consider a six-bill package introduced by seven Democrat members of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives “to encourage the responsible development of A.I. data centers addressing water and energy use, emergency preparedness,” and more.

Pennsylvania has power plants, steel mills, factories, coal mines, and acres of warehouses–all of which deal with a host of regulations to address these same issues. One bill would impose energy-efficiency standards on data centers when there is no more powerful incentive for prudent use of resources than the profit motive.

Why are lawmakers specifically targeting these information processors?

“This is an attempt to throttle new data centers to prevent more natural gas from being used to power them,” writes Jim Willis, publisher of Marcellus Drilling News. “‘Responsible development’ is code for no development.”

A seventh House bill, titled the “Data Center Act,” would require the eponymous facilities to get at least 25 percent of their energy from so-called renewable sources, defined as wind, solar, biomass, and hydroelectric.

Such market meddling has contributed to rising electricity prices and a more fragile power grid by giving preferential treatment to expensive and unreliable energy sources–particularly wind and solar. Moreover, misguided policies have shortened or ended operations for more practical technologies, such as coal- and natural gas-fired power plants.

At a hearing before the Pennsylvania House Committee on Energy, several witnesses cautioned against the bill’s renewable mandate. They included Stephen DeFrank, chairman of the state Public Utility Commission; Joe Bowring, an independent market monitor with PJM Interconnection; Dr. Amy Brinton, director of government affairs with the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry; Rob Bair, president of the Pennsylvania Building and Construction Trades Council; and Dan Diorio, vice president of state policy with the Data Center Coalition.

State Rep. Mike Armanini, one of at least two Republican committee members opposing the mandate, noted that a 2019 proposal by then-Gov. Tom Wolf to impose a tax on fossil fuels had discouraged investment in natural gas plants. He also said that another House committee “would kill the natural gas industry” with a proposal to establish a gas-well setback of nearly a mile.

State Rep. Rob Matzie, a Democrat and the bill’s prime sponsor, agreed that avoiding overregulation was important. But Matzie insisted that policymakers should “promulgate some regulations early from a temporary perspective, and then move forward.”

Perhaps Matzie is testing political winds with the mandate provision. However, once enacted, most regulations are about as “temporary” as the Great Pyramid of Giza.

Enacted two decades ago, the state’s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act (AEPS) cost electricity customers more than $700 million in 2024 in compliance costs alone. Meanwhile, the wind and solar energy it subsidizes remains unreliable and too expensive to survive in a free market.

In Arizona, regulators have voted unanimously to begin repealing that state’s version of AEPS, reports the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). Rating states based on various policies, ALEC ranks Arizona near the top nationally, at second and sixth for economic performance and economic outlook, respectively. On the other hand, Pennsylvania’s rankings are a pathetic 44th and 36th.

Noting Arizona’s economic success, ALEC partially credits the state’s “infrastructure capacity to support resource-intensive industries,” such as data centers that “require dependable, uninterrupted sources of baseload electricity to stay operational.”

If there is to be legislation on data centers, a proposal by state Sen. Camera Bartolotta offers a more viable solution. Barlotta’s bill would expedite permits for projects that meet or exceed federal standards.

Better still would be fulfilling the promise of broad permitting reform in a recent budget agreement. And while budget negotiations ended the threatened implementation of Wolf’s 2019 tax on fossil fuels, Gov. Josh Shapiro should drop his own attempts to tax reliable energy sources and force renewable energy on consumers.

As Rep. Armanini put it: “What are we going to do with Pennsylvania? Are we going to overregulate it and not let [the energy] industry grow? Or are we truly going to work toward Pennsylvania energy dominance? … We need to get into the game of being competitive.”

A competitive Pennsylvania is not out of reach. Thankfully, regulatory reform found its way into the newly minted state budget, suggesting the push for commonsense regulation is quickly gaining momentum in Harrisburg.

Gordon Tomb is a senior fellow with the Commonwealth Foundation, a free-market think tank in Pennsylvania.

name: Texas American Energy
title: Energy storage industry set aggressive goals for 2025 — and already crushed them
description:
So how’d the storage industry do?
In eight years, energy storage went from a tiny player to one of the largest sources of new power on the U.S. grid.
Experts say that lessons learned there can help other regions deploy battery storage onto their grids, including the Midwest and East Coast, which are buckling under the weight of new data center construction.
Sizable Energy is working on a novel way to store power in flexible reservoirs that float in the open ocean.
And, Cache Energy has developed inexpensive pellets of calcium hydroxide that could store energy for months with minimal losses.
text:
Nearly a decade ago, when the energy storage market was in its infancy, an industry organization set a dreamy goal: By the end of 2025, the U.S. would deploy 35 gigawatts of batteries connected to the grid.

So how’d the storage industry do? In the third quarter, 4.7 gigawatts of batteries were installed. In sum, more than 40 gigawatts have been deployed, and the year isn’t over, Canary Media reported. In eight years, energy storage went from a tiny player to one of the largest sources of new power on the U.S. grid.

What’s more, that’s nearly half of all new renewable power deployed on the grid for July through September, and this year, renewables have been the leading source of all new capacity, according to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

Much of the new storage capacity has been deployed in Arizona, California, and Texas, states where the grid has been strained in recent years. Experts say that lessons learned there can help other regions deploy battery storage onto their grids, including the Midwest and East Coast, which are buckling under the weight of new data center construction.

Startups have been taking note.

Redwood Materials, which was co-founded by Tesla alumnus JB Straubel, in June added a new business line focused on repurposing used EV batteries for grid-scale storage. The company noticed two overlapping trends: The batteries that were arriving at its recycling facilities still had plenty of life left in them, and meanwhile, the battery storage industry was growing in leaps and bounds.

By 2028, Redwood plans to deploy 20 gigawatt-hours’ worth of battery storage. Investors have voiced their approval, investing another $350 million in the company to propel the new business line.

Another startup, Base Power, has taken a slightly different tack, leasing batteries to homeowners and aggregating them to serve as a large virtual power plant. The Austin-based startup raised $1 billion in October to help build a battery factory and fuel its expansion beyond Texas. The company has deployed more than 100 megawatt-hours of batteries in Texas.

While lithium-ion batteries have dominated new installations, other startups are pursuing other technologies that could lower storage costs significantly.

Sizable Energy is working on a novel way to store power in flexible reservoirs that float in the open ocean. Fourth Power is using blocks of carbon to store heat at super-high temperatures, and it’s looking to deploy them in 2028 at a cost that’s lower than lithium-ion batteries or peaking natural gas power plants. XL Batteries is deploying its flow-battery technology at petrochemical storage sites, allowing it to store hundreds of megawatt-hours using existing infrastructure. And, Cache Energy has developed inexpensive pellets of calcium hydroxide that could store energy for months with minimal losses.

description:
The California Coastal Commission is deciding next week how long Diablo Canyon, the state’s last nuclear power plant, can keep operating.
Pacific Gas & Electric, which owns the Diablo Canyon Power Plant, needs approval from the Coastal Commission to keep it running after it was scheduled to shut down this year.
Why Lawmakers Are Talking About the Plant Now Diablo Canyon is a 40-year-old power plant in Avila Beach that generates about 9 percent of the state’s total energy.
The legislation to keep Diablo Canyon open, SB 846, allowed PG&E to do this because it’s seen as an asset to everyone in the state.

text:
The California Coastal Commission is deciding next week how long Diablo Canyon, the state’s last nuclear power plant, can keep operating.

Pacific Gas & Electric, which owns the Diablo Canyon Power Plant, needs approval from the Coastal Commission to keep it running after it was scheduled to shut down this year. It’s one of the last permits needed to stay open after lawmakers approved it to continue operating until 2030.

Although situated 325 miles north of San Diego on the Central Coast, what happens within the plant’s concrete domes has implications for the Southern California metropolitan area, too.

Ahead of next week’s meeting, I wanted to get a better understanding of Diablo Canyon’s importance, the decades-long controversy that surrounds it, and what its continued operation means for ratepayers in San Diego.

Why Lawmakers Are Talking About the Plant Now

Diablo Canyon is a 40-year-old power plant in Avila Beach that generates about 9 percent of the state’s total energy. Its towering concrete cylinders and highlighter-green control room simulator are a snapshot in time, largely unchanged from when the plant began operating. Plans to phase it out in 2025 commenced nearly a decade ago.

Gov. Gavin Newsom in 2022 authorized the plant to stay open past its scheduled closure this year after heat-related blackouts the year prior sparked concerns over the reliability of California’s power grid.

Lawmakers pushed through a $1.4 billion state loan to keep it open, against the wishes of some Democrats skeptical of continuing to include nuclear power in the state’s portfolio of clean energy.

The Plant Remains Controversial Despite Growing Popularity of Nuclear Energy

The plant has been marred by controversy since it began operating off the San Luis Obispo coast in 1985. Advocacy groups such as Mothers for Peace have scrutinized its two nuclear reactors for decades over concerns about its waste, which remains radioactive for centuries.

Critics also point to the 2.5 billions of gallons of sea water it pulls in from the Pacific Ocean each day to cool its systems, its damage to marine life, and crisscrossing earthquake fault lines near its reactors as other dangers.

PG&E has maintained the plant is safe to operate and produces little carbon pollution, something proponents of nuclear energy and policymakers have largely embraced as the need for energy continues to grow statewide and nuclear reactors become a more attractive option.

Costs to Keep the PG&E Plant Open Are Hitting Ratepayers’ Pocketbooks, Including in San Diego

How the operators will afford to keep the plant running has been a questionever since lawmakers approved the $1.4 billion loan to keep it open for the next five years, which was to be paid back through federal loans and, if those didn’t fully materialize, profits generated from 2029 to 2030.

As much as $588 million is unlikely to come in, due to insufficient federal funding and projected profits, a report by CalMatters found.

Last year, the California Public Utilities Commission approved $722 million in ratepayer funds to go toward the plant’s operating costs this year. Those rate hikes were spread across customers of all the major investor-owned companies for the first time in history, including Southern California Edison and San Diego Gas & Electric, because its power helps offset costs for all customers, PG&E said at the time.

That meant SDG&E customers paid $2 a month on average this year to help fund the plant, according to reporting from the San Francisco Chronicle.

The legislation to keep Diablo Canyon open, SB 846, allowed PG&E to do this because it’s seen as an asset to everyone in the state. PG&E has forecast it will cost SDG&E customers $12.6 million in 2026.

This is in addition to rising electricity bills for Californians, which are already among the highest in the country.

Nuclear energy critics and consumer advocates say that burdening ratepayers to fund Diablo Canyon and its environmental impacts are reasons to demand certain conservation requirements from the company to move forward with the permitting process.

The Coastal Commission Is Requiring PG&E to Conserve Land Around the Plant to Keep Operating

Last month, commission staff recommended that 1,100 of the 12,000 acres owned by the company at the site be set aside for conservation and public access to compensate for the estimated 2.5 billion larval fish the plant damages each year.

They also recommended increasing the acreage amount from 1,100 to 3,300 if the plant is approved to operate past 2030, which PG&E is seeking to do with federal regulators.

Commissioners took issue with the staff’s recommendation, wanting more concessions from the company to conserve a larger portion of the Diablo Canyon lands before giving the OK.

This is what the Dec. 11 hearing will be about, and commissioners are expected to approve the permit.

Sen. John Laird and Assemblymember Dawn Addis, both Democrats, wrote a letter to the commission ahead of its November meeting urging them to require PG&E to conserve more land because there was no guarantee that the state would allow the plant to continue running past 2030.

“We are not attempting to reject this permit application to extend Diablo Canyon’s operation until 2030,” Laird said in a statement after the November meeting. “The issue before the commission is rather how much of the Diablo Canyon lands to protect.”

What I’m Reading Now

UC San Diego says one in eight of its students is struggling with remedial math, KPBS reports.

Republican Rep. Darrell Issa says he’s no longer considering a congressional run in Texas, explained by The San Diego Union Tribune.

Oh, you didn’t know? Imported flowers are out, homegrown flowers are in. At least among Gen Z and millennials, the Associated Press writes.

title: Senate votes to reopen Alaska Coastal Plain to energy leasing - The Black Chronicle
description:
Federal lease sales in Alaska will now revert to a framework developed in 2020 by the Trump administration that had opened most of the Coastal Plain to oil and gas development.
In October, the Interior Department said it would move to restore lease sales to the entire Coastal Plain as part of Trump’s U.S. energy dominance agenda.
Sen. Lisa Murkowski said after the vote that a return to “balanced management” on the Coastal Plain will support U.S. energy independence.
Kristen Moreland, executive director of the Gwich’in Steering Committee, a group formed in 1988 by Alaska Natives opposed to oil drilling on the Coastal Plain, said the Senate vote ignored local concerns.
The group has said the Coastal Plain is a critical habitat for Porcupine caribou.
text:
(The Center Square) – The U.S. Senate voted Thursday to overturn a Biden-era policy that restricted oil and gas drilling in most of the Arctic Wildlife Refuge’s Coastal Plain, advancing a Trump administration effort to open the area to energy development.

In a 49-45 vote, the Senate passed a resolution overturning a 2024 Interior Department plan that would have limited oil and gas lease sales to about 400,000 acres within the 1.56-million-acre Arctic Wildlife Refuge. One Republican senator, Susan Collins of Maine, voted with Democrats to oppose the resolution. The legislation is now on the president’s desk awaiting signature.

Federal lease sales in Alaska will now revert to a framework developed in 2020 by the Trump administration that had opened most of the Coastal Plain to oil and gas development. In October, the Interior Department said it would move to restore lease sales to the entire Coastal Plain as part of Trump’s U.S. energy dominance agenda.

The president’s One Big Beautiful Bill, passed in July, includes provisions mandating six oil and gas lease sales in the Cook Inlet Planning Area in Alaska’s federal waters between 2026 and 2032, compared to two auctions covering the same area during the Biden administration.

Alaska’s all-Republican congressional delegation introduced and cosponsored the legislation. Sen. Lisa Murkowski said after the vote that a return to “balanced management” on the Coastal Plain will support U.S. energy independence.

Kristen Moreland, executive director of the Gwich’in Steering Committee, a group formed in 1988 by Alaska Natives opposed to oil drilling on the Coastal Plain, said the Senate vote ignored local concerns. The group has said the Coastal Plain is a critical habitat for Porcupine caribou.

“This action from DC ignores years of consultation and communication with our Gwich’in communities that rely on this landscape for not only our subsistence and survival, but also our culture and spiritual health and well-being,” Moreland said on the group’s website. “We stand united in our opposition to any oil and gas development in the Arctic Refuge and will continue to fight this effort from the Trump administration and decision-makers who ignore our voices.”

Earthjustice, a nonprofit environmental law organization, also said the vote prioritizes energy production over wildlife protections.

Groups supporting the push to open the Refuge to energy production include Voice of the Arctic Iñupiat, whose members include leaders living in the North Slope region; Kaktovik Iñupiat Corp, the village corporation for Kaktovik, the only community located within the coastal plain; and North Slope Borough, a local government organization in Alaska that supports resource development to fund essential services like schools, infrastructure and emergency services.

As mandated by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act passed by Congress in 2017, the first-ever lease sale of tracts in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge occurred on Jan. 6, 2021.

Seven of the nine bids accepted at the 2021 auction went to the Alaska Industrial Development and Export Authority, a state-owned corporation, but those leases were canceled by the Biden administration in September 2023.

In March 2025, a U.S. District Court judge ruled the Biden administration had failed to follow the congressionally mandated procedure before canceling the leases, and ordered the Interior Department to vacate the cancelation.

title: Provincial Changes Bill 68 - Upper Thames River Conservation Authority
description:
On November 7, 2025, the Province opened public consultation on an Environmental Registry of Ontario (ERO #025-1257) proposal to consolidate Ontario’s 36 conservation authorities into 7 large regional authorities.
Under this proposal, a new Lake Erie Regional Conservation Authority would be created by merging eight existing conservation authorities — Catfish Creek, Essex Region, Grand River, Kettle Creek, Long Point Region, Lower Thames Valley, St. Clair Region, and Upper Thames River.
This new regional conservation authority would span a large geographic area from Windsor through London, Brantford, and north of Waterloo and include 81 municipalities.
The proposed consolidation follows on the heels of changes made to the Conservation Authorities Act, including the establishment of a new agency, the Ontario Provincial Conservation Agency, to provide leadership, governance, and strategic direction to conservation authorities (CAs).
The changes to the Act were part of Bill 68, “Plan to Protect Ontario Act” which was introduced and passed without any consultation.
text:
On November 7, 2025, the Province opened public consultation on an Environmental Registry of Ontario (ERO #025-1257) proposal to consolidate Ontario’s 36 conservation authorities into 7 large regional authorities. Under this proposal, a new Lake Erie Regional Conservation Authority would be created by merging eight existing conservation authorities — Catfish Creek, Essex Region, Grand River, Kettle Creek, Long Point Region, Lower Thames Valley, St. Clair Region, and Upper Thames River. This new regional conservation authority would span a large geographic area from Windsor through London, Brantford, and north of Waterloo and include 81 municipalities.

The proposed consolidation follows on the heels of changes made to the Conservation Authorities Act, including the establishment of a new agency, the Ontario Provincial Conservation Agency, to provide leadership, governance, and strategic direction to conservation authorities (CAs). The changes to the Act were part of Bill 68, “Plan to Protect Ontario Act” which was introduced and passed without any consultation.

Your Voice Matters

The UTRCA Board of Directors strongly encourages our watershed partners and interest-holders to carefully evaluate the Province’s proposal to consolidate the CAs. This proposal has serious, long-lasting implications for local watershed management.

ERO #025-1257 is open for public comment until December 22, 2025.

Submit your comments at https://ero.ontario.ca/notice/025-1257

title: Targa Badlands LLC faced with $500000 fine for Clean Air Act violation over Johnson ...
description:

Targa Badlands LLC had pleaded guilty to the offense earlier this year.
According to the press release, Targa Badlands LLC was also responsible for self-identifying, self-reporting, and correcting the failure.
“At the same time, we recognize that Targa Badlands LLC took responsibility for its actions and self-reported the violation.
Targa Badlands LLC operated the Station between 2018 and 2022.
text:
BISMARCK — Targa Badlands LLC, which operated the Johnson Compressor Station in Dunn County from 2018 to 2022, was sentenced today for failing to timely install continuous parameter monitoring systems on certain engines at the site, said the U.S. Attorney Nicholas W. Chase. The failure, according to a press release, could lead to increased hazardous air pollutants being released into the environment.

The penalties the company faces include three years of probation, 500 hours of community service to the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara (MHA) Nation, and payment of a $500,000 National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (“NESHAP”) Clean Air Act violation fine.

Targa Badlands LLC had pleaded guilty to the offense earlier this year.

According to the press release, Targa Badlands LLC was also responsible for self-identifying, self-reporting, and correcting the failure.

“Today’s sentence underscores the importance of enforcing our environmental laws, which protect the land, water, and communities,” said US Attorney Chase. “At the same time, we recognize that Targa Badlands LLC took responsibility for its actions and self-reported the violation. Natural gas production is vital to our state’s economy, and it must be done responsibly. This case demonstrates that we can support strong energy production while holding companies accountable when they fall short of their legal obligations.”

Under NESHAP, Targa Badlands LLC was required to timely install continuous parameter monitoring systems on two engines in the Johnson Compressor Station, located in Dunn County. Targa Badlands LLC operated the Station between 2018 and 2022. Continuous parameter monitoring systems monitor and collect data on temperature and pressure for engine operations to ensure the catalyst is being utilized properly, thereby ensuring that the engine does not produce excess emissions.

The 2025 case against Targa Badlands LLC followed two earlier occasions in which the company had agreed to pay civil penalties to the United States for separate NESHAP violations pertaining to natural gas compressor stations operated by the company on the Fort Berthold Indian Reservation, according to a press statement.

According to the press release, the company has updated their policy and procedural best practices to improve their environmental permit review and implementation process.

The case was investigated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency – Criminal Investigation Division investigated the case and Assistant United States Attorney Jonathan J. O’Konek was the prosecutor.
